title: 103_hr3835
content: The Act titled "National Voter Opportunity To Inform Congress Effectively (V.O.I.C.E.) on Term Limits Act of 1994" is referred to as the short title. The findings and purposes of the Act are outlined in Section 2. The Congress finds that the right to vote and have a voice in Congress are fundamental rights, there is a growing demand for term limits on Members of Congress, and voters in multiple states have already approved laws to limit congressional terms. The Act aims to allow citizens to vote on limiting the terms of Members of Congress and to conduct a national nonbinding referendum on term limits in 1994. It also seeks to explore the possibility of future national referenda on important issues. The Act aims to allow citizens to vote on limiting the terms of Members of Congress and to conduct a national nonbinding referendum on term limits in 1994. It also seeks to explore the possibility of future national referenda on important issues. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines terms such as "nonbinding referendum" as a question on the general election ballot in 1994, "advisory question" as the National Advisory Referendum on Term Limits, "general election" as the 1994 election for Federal officers, and "Federal office" as various positions in the United States Congress. The term "State election agency" refers to the official agency in each State and territory responsible for conducting general elections. SEC. 4 of the Act mandates placing an advisory question on term limits for Members of Congress on the 1994 general election ballot in every congressional district, delegate district, and resident commissioner district in the United States, including the District of Columbia and territories. The Clerk of the United States House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate are required to certify the ballot title and question by August 1, 1994. The Act mandates placing an advisory question on term limits for Members of Congress on the general election ballot in every congressional district. Ballots will include the advisory question for voters to decide on limiting the number of terms for House Representatives and Senators. The Act mandates placing an advisory question on term limits for Members of Congress on the general election ballot in every congressional district. Ballots will be prepared for voters to participate in the nonbinding referendum, with costs reimbursed by the United States for districts not holding a general election in November 1994. The Act mandates placing an advisory question on term limits for Members of Congress on the general election ballot in every congressional district. Costs will be reimbursed by the United States for districts not holding a general election in November 1994. The Clerk of the United States House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate will ensure proper application and reimbursement of expenses. State election agencies will tabulate and certify the voting results in the same manner as elections for Members of Congress. Certified results will be transmitted to the Congress and all Members. The official, certified election results of each jurisdiction's nonbinding referendum on the advisory question shall be certified by the State election agency to the Clerk of the United States House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate. The results will be transmitted to each Member of Congress and reviewed by the respective Committee on the Judiciary for recommendations. Within 6 months of the general election, recommendations for response to nonbinding referenda must be reported to the House and Senate. State election agencies must provide suggestions for improving future nonbinding referenda procedures within 90 days of the election. Comments will be forwarded to the respective Judiciary committees in the House and Senate. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act shall become effective immediately upon passage.
